Consider the computation of the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}\\{ x(t) \\} \\) of a function \\( x(t) \\). Here, \\( x(t) \\) is described by the time-domain differential equation \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + Bu \\), where \\( A \\) and \\( B \\) are matrices, and \\( u(t) \\) is an input signal or control function. The Fourier transform is taken with respect to the function after applying a linear transformation \\( f(x) = Dx \\), where \\( D \\) is a constant matrix.

After computing the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}\\{ x(t) \\} \\) at t = T, can we trace back and determine if the transformation \\( f(x) = Dx \\) was applied at \\( t = 0 \\) without intervention?
Explanation: The Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}\\{ x(t) \\} \\) at \\( t = T \\) contains detailed frequency information, but it does not necessarily isolate the effects of the linear transformation \\( Dx \\) applied at \\( t = 0 \\). Multiple transformations can result in the same frequency-domain representation when combined with the effects of \\( Ax + Bu \\).
